author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California Tries Paying Drug Users to Stay Sober
description: The state is testing a program, run through Medicaid, that lets methamphetamine users earn gift cards by testing negative.
content: California began a bold experiment this year: paying people to stay sober.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts and Nichole Manna
title: Grief and Anger Continue to Reverberate From Jacksonville Shootings
description: New details emerge from the racially motivated attacks on Saturday.
content: Two days after a gunman killed three Black people at a Dollar General store in Jacksonville, Fla., in a racially motivated attack, and as grief and anger reverberated through the community, new details about the gunman’s writings and the timeline of events continued to emerge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: How Do We Manage China’s Decline?
description: Forget Thucydides’ trap. China is stuck in a version of Tocqueville’s paradox.
content: Several years ago, the Harvard political scientist Graham Allison coined the term “Thucydides’ trap.” It was based on the ancient historian’s observation that the real cause of the Peloponnesian War “was the rise of Athens and the fear that this instilled in Sparta.” Allison saw the pattern of tensions — and frequent wars — between rising and ruling powers repeating itself throughout history, most recently, he believes, with the challenge that a rising China poses to American hegemony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Tennessee Session Ends in Chaos, With No Action on Gun Control
description: A special legislative session devoted to public safety became a venue for bitter fights over free speech and dissent. The Republican supermajority called an end to it on Tuesday without enacting major policy changes.
content: Tennessee Republicans on Tuesday ended a special session of the state legislature devoted to public safety without passing any new restrictions on firearm access, bringing to a close an emotional and chaotic week that was punctuated by tearful pleas from parents whose children survived a mass shooting at a Nashville Christian school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Wait, Is That Rapid Test Really Expired?
description: As Covid cases rise, at-home tests are a critical tool to keep yourself and others safe. Here are answers to a few common questions about when and how to use them.
content: Since the public health emergency expired, lab P.C.R. tests — the gold standard for detecting Covid-19 — have become more expensive and less accessible for many people. That largely leaves us with at-home rapid tests. As cases climb in some areas and reinfections crop up, here’s a refresher on how to use the tests most effectively.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle and Mira Rojanasakul
title: Five Takeaways From Our Investigation Into America’s Groundwater Crisis
description: Aquifers are shrinking nationwide, threatening supplies of drinking water and America’s status as a food superpower. Climate change is amplifying the problem.
content: A New York Times investigation has found that America is depleting its invaluable reserves of groundwater at a dangerous rate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nichole Manna and Anna Betts
title: The Lives Lost to the Jacksonville Gunman
description: A community remembers a recent high school graduate, a women known as a bright soul and a doting dad, all victims of a racial shooting.
content: There was the picture of Anolt Joseph Laguerre Jr., known as A.J., big as life at 18 in the red satin cap and gown he’d worn in May 2022 as he walked across the stage at his graduation from William M. Raines High School.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Richarz
title: Japan Rail Pass, One of Travel’s Great Deals, Gets Pricier
description: After decades without a significant increase, the price of the passes is jumping by as much as 76 percent. But that doesn’t mean they aren’t still a good value, if you know how to use them.
content: Since 1981, the Japan Rail Pass has provided overseas visitors with budget-friendly access to unlimited rides on the country’s local and regional lines, as well as the famed shinkansen bullet trains, which can reach an operational speed of 200 miles per hour, at prices unchanged in decades. Indeed, visitors to Japan in 2023 pay the same unadjusted amount for a two-week rail pass as they did in 1989.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: How Trump’s Election Lies Left the Michigan G.O.P. Broken and Battered
description: Infighting between Trump acolytes and traditionalists has driven away donors and voters. Can the Michigan Republican Party rebuild in time for the presidential election?
content: The Michigan Republican Party is starving for cash. A group of prominent activists — including a former statewide candidate — was hit this month with felony charges connected to a bizarre plot to hijack election machines. And in the face of these troubles, suspicion and infighting have been running high. A recent state committee meeting led to a fistfight, a spinal injury and a pair of shattered dentures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Cannabis Use Disorder Is ‘Common’ Among Marijuana Users, Study Finds
description: Medical and recreational users alike are susceptible to problematic use of marijuana.
content: More than one-fifth of people who use cannabis struggle with dependency or problematic use, according to a study published on Tuesday in The Journal of the American Medical Association Network Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: It’s Time to Talk About ‘Pandemic Revisionism’
description: The epidemiologist Katelyn Jetelina takes stock of school closures, mask mandates and the pandemic response.
content: Should schools have been closed down? Were lockdowns a mistake? Was masking even effective? Was the economic stimulus too big?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Su and Alexander Stockton
title: ‘It’s Affirmative Action for the Rich.’ Five Legacy Students Spoke to Us About Their Privilege.
description: They benefited from legacy admissions, and they want it to end.
content: A lot of people have recently weighed in on legacy admissions, the preferential treatment given to the children of alumni in the college application process: President Biden. Members of Congress. Supreme Court justices. Officials at numerous colleges — some defending the practice, others calling to ditch it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: An American Tragedy at the Dollar General
description: Education alone may not be the answer to heal racism, but what cannot be faced cannot be healed.
content: When I was a child, I loved going to the Dollar General. It was the one place I could pick out any toy I wanted, confident that my mother wouldn’t turn me down because it was too expensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher
title: U.S. Does Not Want to ‘Decouple’ From China, Commerce Chief Says
description: Gina Raimondo, the commerce secretary, emphasized U.S. concerns over harsh treatment of foreign companies and national security issues in a meeting with top officials in Beijing.
content: Gina Raimondo, the U.S. secretary of commerce, told Chinese officials on Tuesday that the United States was not seeking to sever economic ties with China, but she expressed a litany of concerns that were prompting the business community to describe China as “uninvestable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Does Blending Fruit in a Smoothie Affect Its Nutrients?
description: We have good news and a little advice for smoothie lovers.
content: Q: If I blend fruits and vegetables into a smoothie, do they lose nutrients or fiber?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Vatican Tries to Clarify Pope Francis’ Remarks on Russia
description: The Holy See sought to calm an outcry over comments that some critics said were too close to President Vladimir Putin’s justifications for invading Ukraine.
content: Pope Francis did not intend to “glorify imperialistic logic” in off-the-cuff remarks last week about expansionist 18th-century Russian rulers, the Vatican said on Tuesday, seeking to calm an outcry over comments that some critics said were too close to President Vladimir V. Putin’s justifications for invading Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Offshore Wind Auction for the Gulf of Mexico Gets a Tepid Response
description: The Biden administration has bet big on offshore wind. But the first-ever auction in the Gulf of Mexico attracted just two bidders.
content: The first auction of leases for wind farms in the Gulf of Mexico, which the Biden administration had heralded as part of its effort to expand clean energy, ended on Tuesday with just one of three available tracts sold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Luis Rubiales and Spain’s Kiss Scandal at the World Cup, Explained
description: An unwanted kiss cast a pall over the Spanish team’s victory at the Women’s World Cup. Some are calling it a #MeToo moment for the country and for soccer there.
content: When the Spanish women’s national soccer team won the World Cup final this month, their compatriots had little time to celebrate before the behavior of the country’s top soccer official prompted a controversy over misogyny and sexual assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Hurricane Idalia Is Aiming for Florida’s Big Bend Region
description: The marshy coast of sparsely populated wetlands is known for its freshwater springs and tiny fishing villages.
content: Hurricane Idalia is expected to make landfall early Wednesday along Florida’s Big Bend, a marshy coast of sparsely populated wetlands known for its freshwater springs and tiny fishing villages — including Cedar Key, a conglomeration of tiny islands connected by small bridges, where a deadly storm struck in 1896 and killed at least 70 people in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Hurricane Idalia Barrels Toward Florida
description: Also, the U.S. announces drugs subject to price negotiation. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: With sustained winds of near 100 miles per hour, Hurricane Idalia is nearing Florida’s Gulf Coast, where it is expected to deliver dangerous winds and a life-threatening storm surge by the time it makes landfall tomorrow morning. Rain from the storm’s outer bands has already begun to lash Florida’s southwest coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Secon
title: Where Tech Investors Are Buying Up Land, Locals Are Worried
description: In Solano County, Calif., longtime residents are both worried and baffled by an ambitious plan to build a city where there is now mostly farmland.
content: In a rural slice of California’s Solano County, between the cities of the Bay Area and Sacramento, rumors have been swirling for years about “the Flanneries,” a mystery company buying up mostly undeveloped land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: A S.A.D. Story: What Can We Learn from the 1970s?
description: Not all inflations and disinflations are the same.
content: In my experience, economic pundits all too often suffer from S.A.D. — not seasonal affective disorder, a form of depression that afflicts many people during the dark winter months, but seventies analogy disorder, a propensity to react to any hint of inflation with the assertion that the stagflation of the 1970s has made a comeback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour Speed Round, Part 1
description: A conversation about how the concert relates to Beyoncé’s stadium show, the role of dance in Swift’s spectacular and more.
content: The first leg of Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour has come to a close, with the pop superstar having performed in stadiums across North America for several million people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Coral Davenport
title: After Supreme Court Forces Its Hand, E.P.A. Curbs Wetlands Protection
description: The agency curtailed pollution protections for millions of streams, wetlands and other bodies of water to comply with a Supreme Court decision.
content: The Biden administration on Tuesday lifted protections from pollution for millions of acres of wetlands, three months after the Supreme Court found that it lacked the authority to regulate them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Wildfires Burn Across Louisiana, Killing 2
description: The wildfires in Southwestern Louisiana are among the worst in the state’s history and have burned an estimated 60,000 acres.
content: Hundreds of wildfires burning across Louisiana have killed two people and burned through an estimated 60,000 acres of land, state officials said on Tuesday as they warned that the dangerously dry conditions are expected to continue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Ginger Chicken With Peanut Sauce, Coconut Rice With Shrimp and Corn
description: These weeknight dinner solutions are reader favorites and take advantage of summer produce.
content: We recently published a collection of the 50 most popular recipes of the year so far on New York Times Cooking. If nothing else, I hope it reminds you to make our furikake tomato sandwiches while supplies last (and by that I mean audaciously juicy summer tomatoes), and that there are few pleasures more pure than plunging deep into a bowl of Magnolia Bakery banana pudding.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Trial for Trump Is Set for March in Federal Case
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 29, 2023.
content: “Mr. Trump, like any defendant, will have to make the trial date work regardless of his schedule.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: The Blue Supermoon: A Gem in the Night Sky
description: The next full moon, the second this month, is a celestial rarity. It will also be bigger and brighter than usual.
content: The lunar fanfare of August is wrapping up with a treat: a blue supermoon that will occur on Wednesday at 9:36 p.m. Eastern time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Katie Couric, Anna Wintour and Danny DeVito Party Before the U.S. Open
description: The U.S.T.A. Foundation hosted a gala, and John McEnroe held a tournament to raise money for tennis scholarships and community programs.
content: On Monday evening, the first day of the U.S. Open, actors, designers and former professional athletes walked into a side entrance, lined with tennis fans at Arthur Ashe Stadium in Flushing Meadows Corona Park in Queens. They walked a blue carpet, the same color as the famous courts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Pat Corrales, Manager of Three Major League Teams, Dies at 82
description: The first big league manager of Mexican descent and a former catcher, he led teams in Texas, Cleveland and Philadelphia.
content: Pat Corrales, who managed the Texas Rangers, Cleveland Indians and Philadelphia Phillies before a long stint on the Atlanta Braves coaching staff under the Hall of Fame skipper Bobby Cox, died on Sunday at his home in the north Georgia mountains. The first Major League manager of Mexican descent, he was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Chaundler and Aaron Boxerman
title: Pressure Mounts on Spanish Soccer Chief Over Nonconsensual Kiss at World Cup
description: Luis Rubiales has defied calls to resign, now echoed by his own federation. Soccer’s world governing body has suspended him, and prosecutors have opened an investigation.
content: The pressure is growing on Luis Rubiales, president of Spain’s national soccer federation, to quit, nine days after he forcibly kissed a member of the country’s victorious women’s World Cup team, igniting a national controversy over sexism in soccer and prompting calls for his resignation from government ministers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Looks for New Ways to Energize Black Voters
description: With much of his racial equity agenda thwarted by Congress or the courts, President Biden is trying to close an enthusiasm gap among the voters who helped deliver him to the White House.
content: During a recent town hall with the Congressional Black Caucus, Vice President Kamala Harris offered a gut check to the 200 people who had gathered to take stock of the state of civil rights in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Rammstein Singer Till Lindemann Is Cleared of Sexual Assault Allegations
description: Berlin’s public prosecutor’s office dropped its investigation, citing a lack of evidence for allegations that Mr. Lindemann had drugged young women in order to have sex with them.
content: Berlin’s public prosecutor’s office on Tuesday said it had dropped its sexual assault investigation into Till Lindemann, the frontman for the rock band Rammstein, citing a lack of evidence.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Summer of Live Music, From Stadiums to Clubs
description: Hear songs from Beyoncé, Alvvays, Mdou Moctar and more.
content: I sincerely hope I am not the first person to break this news to you, but it’s true: Summer is almost over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Danny Hakim
title: Court Skirmishes Show Divergent Strategies by Prosecutors in Trump Cases
description: In Washington, the special counsel is pursuing a streamlined approach and has gotten an early trial date. In Georgia, a more comprehensive indictment faces slower going.
content: While a federal judge was fast-tracking the start of former President Donald J. Trump’s election interference trial in Washington on Monday, the sprawling prosecution of Mr. Trump and 18 co-defendants by the district attorney in Fulton County, Ga., on similar state charges showed signs of slowing to a slog in Atlanta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Benjamin Mueller
title: Scalise, No. 2 House Republican, Says He Has Blood Cancer
description: The Louisiana Republican said he had been diagnosed with multiple myeloma, but would return to Washington to continue working as he undergoes treatment.
content: Representative Steve Scalise, Republican of Louisiana and the majority leader, said Tuesday he had been diagnosed with a rare form of blood cancer but planned to return to Washington to continue working as he undergoes treatment over the next several months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Two Languages Walk Into a Bar
description: A linguistic evolution is taking place in Miami, where some bilingual residents are speaking English “in Spanish.”
content: I have been asked often these days about a recent study on a form of Spanish-influenced English that has emerged in Miami. It is by the linguist Phillip Carter at Florida International University, assisted by Kristen D’Alessandro Merii.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: ‘I Struggled to Understand the Concept of Love’: The Week 10 Winner of Our Summer Reading Contest
description: As our contest comes to a close, we honor Ruby N., and hear from some of our New York Times judges about what it was like to read responses from teenagers around the world.
content: Our Summer Reading Contest is our longest-running challenge and perhaps our simplest: To participate, all you have to do is answer the question, What got your attention in The Times this week?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Bitcoin Jumps as Court Ruling Paves Way for Cryptocurrency E.T.F.
description: A federal appeals court ruled that the Securities and Exchange Commission had wrongfully denied Grayscale Investments’ application to create a cryptocurrency fund that sells on stock exchanges.
content: Cryptocurrency prices jumped on Tuesday after the industry’s largest fund manager scored a legal victory in its long-running attempt to make it easier for investors to put Bitcoin in their portfolios.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: C.E.O.s Side with New York in the Migrant Crisis
description: More than 120 business leaders, including Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase, are urging President Biden and congressional leaders to provide aid to the city.
content: As New York City’s migrant crisis continues to escalate, with more than 100,000 arrivals from the southern U.S. border straining shelters, some of the city’s top business leaders are intervening in a fight over who’s responsible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: An Effort to Focus on Long Overlooked Roma Suffering in the Holocaust
description: As many as a half million Romani people were killed by the Nazis, according to one estimate. A new database tells the story of that genocide and its impact on individual lives.
content: Before the Second World War, Helena Malíková grew up in Uherské Hradiště, a town in Czechoslovakia, where her family lived with other Roma in a settlement of old freight wagons lined up behind a sugar factory, near the Morava River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Imran Khan’s 3-Year Sentence Is Suspended by Pakistan Appeals Court
description: Mr. Khan, who was ousted as prime minister last year, still faces dozens of court cases that could keep him behind bars.
content: An appeals court in Pakistan suspended former Prime Minister Imran Khan’s three-year prison sentence on Tuesday, the latest twist in a political showdown between Mr. Khan and leaders of the powerful military establishment who appear intent on sidelining him from politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: How to Track a Hurricane
description: Idalia’s path makes it difficult to predict where the storm will come ashore.
content: Hurricane Idalia continued to build strength over the Gulf of Mexico’s abnormally warm waters on Tuesday, taking aim at a vulnerable but sparsely populated portion of Florida’s coastline known as the Big Bend, where the peninsula curves west into the Panhandle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Hitting Theater Hard: The Loss of Subscribers Who Went to Everything
description: The subscription model, in which theatergoers buy a season’s worth of shows at a time, had long been waning, but it fell off a cliff during the pandemic.
content: As a group of stagehands assembled train cars for the set of “Murder on the Orient Express,” Ken Martin looked grimly at his email. His first year as artistic director at the Clarence Brown Theater in Knoxville, Tenn., was coming to an end, and the theater had missed its income goals by several hundred thousand dollars, largely because it had lost about half its subscribers since the start of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Valerie Hopkins
title: Past Drones and Sea Mines, a Merchant Ship’s Perilous Journey in Ukraine
description: Ukraine’s Danube River ports have become key arteries for grain exports. But threats from Russia and costly delays have made some shippers rethink their operations in the Black Sea.
content: For five weeks, almost everything seemed to go wrong for one commercial vessel waiting in the Danube River to load Ukrainian grain bound for Spain via the Black Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Politicians to Shein: Not So Fast on U.S. Expansion
description: A group of state attorneys general urged the S.E.C. to make the fast fashion company prove it doesn’t use forced labor if it files to go public.
content: Shein, the ultrafast fashion retailer widely popular among Generation Z and millennial shoppers, faces demands from more than a dozen state attorneys general to answer questions about its business practices as the company’s U.S. expansion continues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Bowling Locale
description: Michèle Govier makes her New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Trump Gets a Trial Date, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: How to Go Camping: A Beginner’s Guide
description: Experts offer tips on what to bring and wear, how to reserve a campsite and extinguish a fire, and other pertinent advice for first-time campers.
content: For first-time campers, spending the night outside presents a planning wilderness, including figuring out what to bring. The following are tips from experts in getting started.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: David Wallace-Wells Interviews Katelyn Jetelina
description: The Aug. 29, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by David Wallace-Wells, with Katelyn Jetelina. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: 3M Says It Will Pay $6 Billion to Resolve Combat Earplug Lawsuits
description: The settlement would end years of litigation brought by military service members and veterans who claimed that the earplugs sold by 3M had led to hearing damage and tinnitus.
content: 3M, the chemical and manufacturing giant, said on Tuesday that it had reached a $6 billion settlement over claims that it sold defective combat earplugs to the U.S. military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Job Openings Dropped in July as Labor Market Cooled
description: Vacancies fell to 8.8 million, the lowest level since March 2021.
content: The number of job openings continued to drop in July, the Labor Department reported Tuesday, another sign that the U.S. labor market is losing its momentum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abigail Geiger
title: Cedar Key Residents in the Path of Idalia Prepare for the Worst
description: The small island city in the Big Bend region of Florida is used to hurricanes, but “this one feels different.” City officials urged residents to evacuate.
content: In Cedar Key — an island city of roughly 700 people in Florida’s Big Bend region — storefronts were boarded up and residents milled about on Tuesday in the slow pace singular to Floridians familiar with such storms. And yet, as the seasonal hurricane ritual started anew and city officials urged people to evacuate, locals expressed a less familiar feeling: worry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Wagner Says Its Chief Has Been Buried, Ending Days of Speculation
description: Details about the funeral for Yevgeny Prigozhin, who died in a plane crash last week along with nine other people, were murky.
content: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the Russian mercenary chief who died in a plane crash last week, has been buried in a private ceremony in St. Petersburg, his press service said on Tuesday, ending days of speculation over how he would be laid to rest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Camille Baker
title: Man Charged With Killing 2-Year-Old Boy Who Disturbed His Sleep
description: Latrell Lewis, 23, was charged with murder after the violence in Brooklyn’s Bergen Beach neighborhood.
content: A 23-year-old man was charged with murder on Monday after he told investigators that he threw his girlfriend’s 2-year-old son against a wall after the boy woke him, according to the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Denver Settles With Black Lives Matter Protesters for $4.7 Million
description: The settlement resolves a class-action lawsuit that accused Denver police officers of using excessive force to control crowds and enforce a curfew in 2020.
content: The authorities in Denver approved a $4.7 million settlement on Monday for more than 300 protesters who were detained for violating an emergency curfew during demonstrations over the killing of George Floyd in 2020, and later accused the police of using excessive force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: In a Decaying Queens Fortress, It’s One Man Versus 47 Kinds of Mosquito
description: Dr. Waheed Bajwa and the Health Department’s Office of Vector Surveillance and Control work all year to protect New York City from a summertime West Nile virus outbreak.
content: In a damp, dungeonlike cell beneath a crumbling military fortress in northeast Queens, Dr. Waheed Bajwa and his team were counting sleeping mosquitoes and trying to divine the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Uncharted Waters
description: The threat to groundwater is a classic tragedy of the commons.
content: The water that lies beneath the earth’s surface — known as groundwater — has been a vital resource for thousands of years. Communities that are far away from lakes and rivers use groundwater to irrigate crops and provide drinking water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Tina Howe, Playwright Best Known for ‘Coastal Disturbances,’ Dies at 85
description: She mixed insight and absurdity in a vast body of work that also included “Painting Churches” and “Pride’s Crossing,” both of which were Pulitzer finalists.
content: Tina Howe, who in plays that could be extravagant productions or small-cast gems zeroed in on the humor, heartache and solidity of her characters’ lives, particularly the female ones, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Lyna Bentahar
title: Wednesday Briefing: U.S. Businesses Say China Is ‘Uninvestable’
description: Also, a legal victory for Imran Khan.
content: Gina Raimondo, the U.S. commerce secretary, told Chinese officials yesterday that the U.S. was not seeking to sever economic ties with China. But she raised a list of concerns that were prompting American businesses to describe China as “uninvestable” because it’s “too risky.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kodé
title: Why Marcia Gay Harden Spends Her Time Off in Upstate New York
description: The actress found a place ‘to plant roots’ on a 300-acre estate in the Catskills: ‘We just saw so much incredible nature here.’
content: Zooming around on an ATV at her property in the Catskills, a couple of hours north of New York City, Marcia Gay Harden pointed out various sights that sparked memories: a back road where she taught her children how to drive; a garden where they picked blueberries; a skate ramp one of her children built; the forsythia trees she planted in honor of her mother, who died in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Dangerous Marketing of the Trump Mug Shot
description: Both sides are trying to profit from reducing this moment to a whole lotta merch.
content: After the mug shot, the marketing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kodé
title: Giuliani’s Upper East Side Apartment Is for Sale
description: Judith Giuliani, his ex-wife, said that it was “no longer a home,” while Mr. Giuliani’s lawyer told a judge recently that the former mayor was “close to broke.”
content: Apartment 10W at 45 East 66th Street went up for sale for $6.5 million in July. The prewar apartment includes “an abundance of sunshine, high ceilings, and beautiful hardwood floors,” according to the listing. The layout is “thoughtful and inviting.” The dining room is “ideal for a tranquil breakfast or cozy dinner.” Oh, and “pets are welcome” in this co-op building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu and Kholood Eid
title: A Toddler’s Long, Slow Road to Recovery After a Shooting
description: Catherine Arias was shot in the head in the Bronx last January. Now 2, she still requires therapy five days a week.
content: It was story time. A pair of 2-year-olds sat on miniature chairs pulled up to a miniature table at Blythedale Children’s Hospital in Valhalla, N.Y., listening attentively.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Gordinier
title: He’s Worked a Lot of Odd Jobs, and Has the Poems to Prove It
description: In “Fixer,” his second collection, the poet Edgar Kunz demonstrates a hard familiarity with the gig economy.
content: In literature as in life, hating your job is an American tradition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Rebecca Robbins
title: U.S. Announces First Drugs Picked for Medicare Price Negotiations
description: The price negotiation program, established by Democrats as part of the Inflation Reduction Act, is projected to save the government tens of billions of dollars in the coming years.
content: The Biden administration on Tuesday unveiled a long-awaited list of the first 10 medicines that will be subject to price negotiations with Medicare, kicking off a landmark program to reduce drug spending that is being fought by the pharmaceutical industry in court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: U.N.C. Graduate Student Is Charged in Fatal Shooting of Professor
description: Tailei Qi, 34, was charged with first-degree murder in the killing of Zijie Yan, an associate professor in the applied physical sciences department, inside a campus lab on Monday.
content: A graduate student at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill has been charged in the fatal shooting of one of his professors on Monday, a killing that spread fear across the campus and forced an hourslong lockdown, according to court documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: Meta’s ‘Biggest Single Takedown’ Removes Chinese Influence Campaign
description: The campaign began at least four years ago and spanned thousands of accounts on Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, X, Substack and Chinese websites, Meta said.
content: On Feb. 27, an article claiming that the United States was behind the bombing of the Nord Stream underwater pipelines in the Baltic Sea was published on the Substack and Blogspot blogging platforms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carolina Abbott Galvão
title: The Only Thing That Helps Me Be in the Moment
description: A writer struggled with being present. This Brazilian drum helped her pay attention.
content: Earlier this year, Paul Simon’s “Me and Julio Down by the Schoolyard” came on at a party I was at. I didn’t recognize the song at first; the room was crowded, and making out Simon’s strumming over multiple streams of chatter and conversation proved difficult. But then I heard it: a sharp noise, cutting through the track’s major chords in jagged intervals like a pair of blunt scissors. When I asked my friend what she thought the sound was, she paused, then guessed it might have been a duck. Another friend likened it to throat singing. They didn’t expect that the alien noise came from a type of drum — the cuíca.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: How Korean Restaurants Remade Fine Dining in New York
description: A cohort of forward-thinking Korean contenders now dominate the city’s high-end restaurant scene the way French cuisine used to.
content: A few months ago, a number of serious food journalists asked out loud whether fine dining was dying, or possibly already dead. This seemed odd to me. I keep close tabs on the restaurant scene, especially in New York City, and if expensive restaurants were undergoing a mass die-off, I’d like to think I would notice. The truth, in fact, seemed to be the opposite. Fancy restaurants are opening here so quickly that there aren’t enough nights in the week for me to check them all out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Georgia School District Canceled an Author’s Talks After He Said ‘Gay’
description: An elementary school principal in Forsyth County emailed parents to apologize last week after Marc Tyler Nobleman used the word in a presentation about the origins of Batman.
content: The principal of a Georgia elementary school apologized to parents last week after a guest author who was discussing his research into a co-creator of Batman told a group of fifth graders that the co-creator’s son was gay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: The A.I. Revolution Is Coming. But Not as Fast as Some People Think.
description: From steam power to the internet, there has always been a lag between technology invention and adoption across industries and the economy.
content: Lori Beer, the global chief information officer of JPMorgan Chase, talks about the latest artificial intelligence with the enthusiasm of a convert. She refers to A.I. chatbots like ChatGPT, with its ability to produce everything from poetry to computer programs, as “transformative” and a “paradigm shift.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: As Teens Take to E-Bikes, Parents Ask: Is This Freedom or Danger?
description: Across the country, parents are expressing a mix of enthusiasm, contrition and uncertainty about the trendy mode of transportation.
content: With e-bikes soaring in popularity, regulators have been unable to keep up with the quickly-evolving market. Safety and law enforcement officials note that many models marketed to children and teenagers exceed legal speed limits and more closely resemble motor vehicles, which require a license and registration to operate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: Hurricane Idalia Threatens to Stir Up Lake Okeechobee’s Toxic Algae Blooms
description: Cyanobacteria have overrun this lake an hour outside West Palm Beach, and excessive rain could spread that algae to nearby waterways.
content: For much of the summer, Lake Okeechobee suffocates under toxic, blue-green algae blooms fed by fertilizer runoff from farms. The blooms recently subsided, but Hurricane Idalia could cause further cycles of growth and rot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Donald Trump’s trial date.
content: A federal judge has set a trial date of March 4 in the prosecution of Donald Trump on charges that he conspired to overturn the 2020 election, rebuffing the former president’s proposal to postpone the trial until 2026. It was an early victory for prosecutors, who had asked for a Jan. 2 date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and David McCabe
title: TikTok’s U.S. Future Still in Limbo as Commerce Secretary Visits China
description: Gina Raimondo, who is in China this week, has said banning TikTok could “lose every voter under 35, forever.”
content: Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo’s visit to China is putting a spotlight on the future of TikTok in the United States, where criticism of the app and its ties to Beijing reached a fever pitch this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Is It Time to Wear a Mask Again?
description: Experts recommend when and how to use them, as Covid continues to circulate.
content: As new Covid variants gain traction, reinfections become more common and cases climb in certain areas, a few schools and businesses are reinstating mask requirements. Experts say it makes sense to increase precautions, including turning back to masks.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Now That We’re Married, What’s Your Name?’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Solitary on my postage stamp porch, I wear Chanel No. 5 and wait, a glass of ruby Beaujolais in hand. A plate with cold green grapes and fat slices of Fontina rests next to me. A soft ocean breeze touches my cheek, carrying the scent of clean salt water. I sip. I wait. I watch. Azure blue fades to delicate gold, chased by a blushing pink horizon. One year ago, I insisted again on a divorce. Now, I revel in a glorious summer sunset. Alone, complete, at peace. — Wendy Maldonado D’Amico
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Steinberger
title: How the War in Ukraine Turned Tennis Into a Battlefield
description: For Ukrainian players, as well as those from Russia and its allies, the unceasing conflict at home has bled into the game. Now they face off at the U.S. Open.
content: It was a few days before the start of Wimbledon this summer, and Elina Svitolina, just off a flight from Geneva, had come to the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club to check in for the tournament. She was returning after a year’s absence. “It feels like it has been 10 years,” she said as she got out of the car. A lot had happened since she last competed at Wimbledon, in 2021. She had given birth to a daughter named Skaï, the first child for her and her husband, the French player Gaël Monfils. Also, her country, Ukraine, had been invaded by Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: In Hilary Leichter’s Multiverse, Your Dream Life Is Always on Deck
description: “Terrace Story” is a novel about generations of women confronting the other side of reality.
content: Priced out of their first home in an unnamed city, a young couple and their infant daughter, Rose, move into a smaller apartment. It’s dark and confined, “the amicable kind of cramped.” When Edward shows it to his wife, Annie, for the first time, he says, “Give it some time, it might grow on you!” She replies, “You mean it might literally grow?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: China’s Economic Outlook: Pep Talks Up Top, Gloom on the Ground
description: Beijing has characterized concerns about the economic slowdown as being inflated by Western critics. Widespread anxiety and pessimism paint a different picture.
content: To the residents and business owners of Chedun, a working-class neighborhood in the southwestern outskirts of Shanghai, the signs of an anemic economy are all around. The factories that once drew workers from around the country have moved away. Those that remain have slashed wages. Around the affordable eateries and motley shops where workers once crowded, employees eagerly latch onto anyone passing by.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Stella Tan, Shannon Lin, M.J. Davis Lin, Michael Benoist, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Sophia Lanman and Chris Wood
title: A Marriage, a Secret and a Crackdown in China
description: The story of a couple torn apart under China’s increasing restrictions.
content: Over the past decade, China has placed more and more restrictions on the lives of its citizens — tightening its hold over what people can do, read and say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Knocked Off Their Perch, the Rangers Hope to Climb Back Up
description: Texas lost eight games in a row, and gave up its long-held lead in the A.L. West. The team hopes Monday’s win over the Mets is the start of something special.
content: This is the first season in Major League Baseball’s modern era in which all teams play each other. It’s about time, really, an easy way to boost the national appeal of a sport that skews regional. Yet some of the matchups still seem a little strange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: Water Main Break in Midtown Manhattan Floods Subway System
description: Service on the 1, 2 and 3 lines resumed with delays hours after a water main broke in Times Square, sending water pouring down onto the tracks and snarling rush hour commutes for 300,000 people.
content: A 120-year-old water main in Times Square burst early Tuesday morning, sending an estimated 1.8 million gallons of water flooding into the subway system and upending the morning commute, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trucks, Cars, Bikes Battling for Space on City Streets
description: Readers react to a guest essay objecting to delivery trucks blocking streets. Also: Fukushima’s water; Mark Meadows; lifesaving abortions; hungry college students.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Ons Jabeur Struggles to a First-Round Win at the U.S. Open
description: Jabeur, who said she had been dealing with an illness before the tournament, appeared weary at the end of the match but nonetheless took the first step toward a repeat run to the final.
content: As Camila Osorio hugged Ons Jabeur at the net following their match on Tuesday, she almost looked as if she were holding Jabeur upright. Jabeur was exhausted and drained, sweat saturating her tennis uniform. She had managed to defeat Osorio, 7-5, 7-6 (4), but she was so weary and wobbly that Osorio asked her if she was OK.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Republicans Target Wisconsin’s Election Chief for Removal, Fueled by Falsehoods
description: Meagan Wolfe, the Wisconsin Elections Commission administrator since 2018, has been demonized by former President Donald J. Trump’s allies in the battleground state.
content: Republicans in Wisconsin pushing to oust the state’s nonpartisan head of elections clashed on Tuesday with voting rights advocates and some local clerks during a rancorous public hearing in Madison, sowing further distrust about voting integrity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas E. Ricks
title: Why Is the Reputation of the U.S. Military Going South So Fast?
description: Republicans are worried about the politics that shape our armed forces. Several recent books look at the good, the bad and the ugly of American military leadership and culture.
content: In the years and months since the U.S. withdrawals from Iraq and Afghanistan, public respect for our armed forces has been plummeting toward levels not seen since the end of the American war in Vietnam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Jeanna Smialek
title: Factories May Be Leaving China, but Trade Ties Are Stronger Than They Seem
description: The United States is trying to lessen its dependence on Chinese goods, but research is showing how tough it is to truly alter global supply chains.
content: The United States has spent the past five years pushing to reduce its reliance on China for computer chips, solar panels and various consumer imports amid growing concern over Beijing’s security threats, human rights record and dominance of critical industries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Hurricane Idalia: Florida’s Evacuation Orders by County
description: Nearly two dozen counties issued evacuation orders ahead of the storm’s arrival.
content: More than 20 counties in western and Central Florida have issued evacuation orders as Hurricane Idalia approaches, including parts of Tampa, the state’s third-largest city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: She Rose From Poverty as China Prospered. Then It Made Her Poor Again.
description: Sun Junli
content: Two years ago, as she walked through a hospital hallway in handcuffs and shackles to get tested for Covid, Sun Junli felt ashamed and defeated. At 45, she had come a long way. The poor village girl in northwestern China had become a successful businesswoman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Tommy Paul the Man Finally Catches Up to Tommy Paul the Tennis Talent
description: After numerous misfires with his career, Paul, an American seeded 14th at the U.S. Open, finds himself as comfortable on the court as off it, and into the second round in Queens.
content: The last time Tommy Paul needed an attitude adjustment, he had just flamed out of a small tournament in the Netherlands in the spring of 2022 in the most petulant way, and his coach had seen enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: When I Tell You Nikki Haley Is Pathetic, That’s an Understatement
description: Don’t be fooled: She’s a shameless opportunist.
content: I wish it were as simple as that one Republican debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin and Anna Kodé
title: President of Powerful Realtors’ Group Resigns After Sexual Harassment Claims
description: Calls for Kenny Parcell to step down from the National Association of Realtors began immediately after The New York Times published an article with complaints of harassment and discrimination from multiple women.
content: The president of the powerful National Association of Realtors has resigned, two days after The New York Times published an article detailing complaints from women that he exhibited a pattern of behavior that included improper touching and sending lewd photos and texts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Former Pediatrician Ordered To Pay $22 Million in Sexual Abuse Suit
description: The judgment is the first handed down against Stuart Copperman. More than 100 similar lawsuits are pending.
content: A Long Island judge has ordered former pediatrician Stuart Copperman to pay $22 million in compensatory and punitive damages to a 42-year-old woman who claimed he had sexually abused her from the time she was a toddler until she turned 18.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: How Might Trump Challenge the March 4 Trial Date in the Federal Election Case?
description: The ex-president vowed to appeal a judge’s decision to schedule the start on his trial the day before Super Tuesday. He can’t disrupt the trial that way, legal experts say — but there is a longer-shot possibility.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump immediately vowed to challenge the March 4 start date for his criminal trial over his efforts to overturn the 2020 election, raising questions of whether or how he could try to push back the timing of the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Katherine Clemmons
title: ‘The Mountain Will Make Cowards Out of All of Us’
description: Two former pro football players entered the Leadville Trail 100-mile race, a grueling slog over Colorado peaks. They were used to challenges, but this was a new kind of pain.
content: Nate Boyer looked up as he began his ascent of Hope Pass about 40 miles into the Leadville Trail 100-mile race. The four-mile section rose 3,200 feet in elevation, taking runners to 12,600 feet above sea level. He would have to conquer the steep grade, run seven miles down the other side to a turnaround and repeat the process. The sun beat down as he maneuvered the trail, devoid of any shade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: anthropomorphize
description: This word has appeared in 13 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word anthropomorphize has appeared in 13 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 11 in “A Chimp Sanctuary With a New Urgency to Give Shelter” by Emmett Lindner, an interview with Emily Anthes:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: ‘No Place for Hate in America,’ Haley Says, Recalling 2015 Church Massacre
description: Nikki Haley, fresh off a strong debate performance last week, was back on the trail and took a moment to condemn the weekend shooting in Jacksonville, Fla.
content: Breaking from her usual stump speech at a South Carolina town hall event on Monday, Nikki Haley paused to condemn a deadly weekend rampage in Jacksonville, Fla., that the authorities were investigating as a hate crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty and Shawn Hubler
title: A California Land Mystery Is Solved. Now the Political Fight Begins.
description: Tech industry investors spent roughly $900 million buying land to build a dream city in a rural part of the Bay Area. It could be years, though, before they can do anything with it.
content: Jan Sramek was 15 years old the first time he tried to get a government to do something he wanted. Back then, he was an internet- and science fiction-obsessed teenager growing up in Drevohostice, in the Czech Republic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Preyed On by Gangs: Gun Violence Surges Within Israel’s Arab Communities
description: At least 155 Arab citizens have died this year in violence largely attributed to organized crime. Some say the government has not done enough to stop the killing.
content: When the shots rang out, the young soccer player was in line at a butcher’s shop in an Arab town in northern Israel. Struck in his leg, he tried to flee, he said. But a black-clad masked gunman chased him, firing into his legs at point-blank range, smashing bones, crushing muscle and severing blood vessels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: At a Rejuvenated Stratford, Second Chances for Plays and Theaters
description: A smash, a romp, a mess and a mystery are part of this Ontario festival’s 12-play repertoire after two seasons of retrenchment.
content: It’s a joyful thing when a great play that seemed to be lost is found. How much more so when its greatness is confirmed and the play takes root in the soil of a new time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: After Florida, Idalia Will Move Through the Southeast
description: The storm could produce flooding, storm surge and even tornadoes through northern Florida, southeastern Georgia and coastal South Carolina in the coming days.
content: Hurricane Idalia poses the most immediate threat to the Gulf Coast of Florida, but forecasters are also warning coastal communities in South Carolina, Georgia and the Atlantic Coast of Florida to prepare for the storm’s effects on Wednesday into Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: With Multiple Battles, Russia and Ukraine Puzzle Over Where to Put Troops
description: Russians are advancing in the Northeast, toward Kupiansk, while Ukraine presses its offensive in the South, each hoping to force the other to redeploy its forces.
content: Russian forces have drawn closer to Kupiansk, in northeastern Ukraine, prompting stepped-up calls for civilians to flee and reflecting the hard choices both sides must make about where to send reinforcements along a front that stretches for hundreds of miles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Hot Ocean Temperatures Could Give Hurricane Idalia a Boost
description: Warm water can fuel tropical storms and hurricanes. This year has been record-breaking for ocean heat.
content: As Hurricane Idalia charges toward Florida, one factor that could amplify its effects on coastal communities is the unusually warm water in the Gulf of Mexico, which is partly the result of the sultry weather that has been smothering the South all summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: U.K. Air Travel Will Be Disrupted for ‘Some Days’ After Traffic Control Glitch
description: The government ruled out a cyberattack as the cause of the technical problems, which forced airlines to cancel about 5 percent of the flights in and out of the country on Tuesday as they tried to catch up.
content: Flights in and out of Britain will be disrupted for days, the U.K. government said on Tuesday, after a technical issue with the country’s air traffic control system left thousands of passengers stranded abroad or facing severe delays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: With Feud Over, New Women’s Ice Hockey League Is Set to Begin
description: Three Canadian and three American teams will begin play in the Professional Women’s Hockey League in January.
content: With a long-running feud in women’s professional ice hockey now settled, a new league with many of the world’s best players is ready to push forward in January, and its inaugural home cities and other details were announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: After Losing Their Homes, Lahaina Parents Try to Save Their School Community
description: Nearly 60 percent of Lahaina students haven’t enrolled in classes after the deadly fire, and families are yearning to rebuild their school network for educational and emotional support.
content: The flames that ripped through Lahaina needed only a few hours to take nearly everything from Aina Kohler. Her house. Her surfing school and cafe. And her parents’ home, where she was raised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: How to Handle Flight Delays and Cancellations
description: Know what airlines can and cannot offer, and where you can go to manage flight changes and updates.
content: With weather being one of the leading causes of air travel delays this year, here’s how to prepare for delays or cancellations during hurricane season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: She Was Depressed and Forgetful. It Was the Worm in Her Brain.
description: Doctors in Australia found a three-inch live parasitic worm in a woman’s brain during surgery after they spent more than a year trying to find the cause of her distress.
content: Doctors in Australia had screened, scanned and tested a woman to find out why she was sick after being hospitalized with abdominal pains and diarrhea. They were not prepared for what they found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Underground Art: A Show Celebrates Subway Posters
description: A Chelsea gallery is displaying works that were originally created as advertisements for the School of Visual Arts.
content: Good morning. Today we’ll look at an exhibition of posters that were originally on the walls of subway stations. For the next two months, they’ll be on the walls of an art gallery. We’ll also find out about birds that are passing through New York on the way south.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Forgotten Radicalism of the March on Washington
description: The struggle for democratic freedom has always been a struggle against the privileges of caste and class.
content: As remembered and commemorated by most Americans, the 1963 March on Washington — its 60th anniversary fell on Monday — represents the essence of the civil rights movement, defined in our national mythology as a colorblind demand for neutrality and fairness in the face of discrimination, embodied in the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s dream that his “four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Discusses Migration With the President of Costa Rica
description: The Biden administration is working with Central American nations like Costa Rica to develop ways for migrants to apply for protection closer to their home countries.
content: President Biden hosted President Rodrigo Chaves of Costa Rica at the White House on Tuesday as their countries try to rein in a surge of migration in the Western Hemisphere.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 29, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Aug. 29, 2023.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a conflict between the maker of a Bella Abzug documentary and Ms. Abzug’s daughter attributed an erroneous distinction to Ms. Abzug’s service in Congress. The first Jewish congresswoman was Florence Prag Kahn, not Ms. Abzug.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Szalavitz
title: Portugal Has Succeeded Where We’ve Failed With Addiction
description: Claims that decriminalization is harmful are not backed by evidence.
content: After Cody Bohanan, 24, was locked up on a charge related to possession of drug paraphernalia in 2021, he told the staff at Butler County Jail in Ohio that he was withdrawing from opioids. His cellmates saw him vomiting blood. They implored guards to intervene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius and Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Family’s Deaths in Locked Apartment Were Murder-Suicide, the Police Say
description: On the Upper West Side, two superintendents went looking for a third who was missing. In his apartment, they found a horror.
content: The men stood in the hallway in front of a locked, fourth-floor apartment door on the Upper West Side on Monday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Totem Pole Taken 94 Years Ago Begins 4,000-Mile Journey Home
description: The 36-foot tall memorial pole has spent almost a century in a Scottish museum. Now it will be returned to the Nisga’a Nation in Canada.
content: Almost 100 years ago, a hand-carved totem pole was cut down in the Nass Valley in the northwest of Canada’s British Columbia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Solomon
title: ‘One Piece’ Creator Hopes to Defy ‘a History of Failure’
description: Live-action manga and anime adaptations have found little success. But in a rare interview, Eiichiro Oda discussed why Netflix’s series could be the exception.
content: On Thursday, an eight-part adaptation of Eiichiro Oda’s pirate comedy-adventure “One Piece” will make its Netflix debut. The stakes are high: Millions of fans want to see if the showrunners, Matt Owens and Steven Maeda (whom Oda describes as “‘One Piece’ superfans”), succeeded in converting the beloved manga and anime series to live-action. Although some viewers over 30 may not recognize the title, “One Piece” is one of the most popular entertainment franchises in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Rumors and Misdirection Keep Crowds Away From Prigozhin Burial
description: The burial of the Wagner mercenary group boss, two months after his mutiny, was shrouded in misinformation, preventing a public display of support the Kremlin did not want to see.
content: Even in death, the movements of Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the Russian mercenary boss, were the subject of intense interest, contradictory reporting and cultivated confusion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Francis Suarez Drops Out of the G.O.P. Presidential Race
description: The mayor of Miami, who had announced his run in June, had not qualified for the first Republican debate last week.
content: Mayor Francis X. Suarez of Miami dropped out of the race for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination on Tuesday, after failing to gain traction in a crowded field and falling short of the requirements to participate in the first Republican debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Fleischman
title: What Fani Willis Got Wrong in Her Trump Indictment
description: The costs of complexity.
content: By assembling a sprawling, 19-defendant RICO indictment with 41 counts, District Attorney Fani Willis of Fulton County has brought the sort of charging instrument that has typically led to monthslong trials, complicated appeals and exhaustion for the participating attorneys. Now, as some co-defendants seek federal removal while others demand speedy trials in state court, we are starting to see the costs of complexity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: So You’re Done With ‘Suits’ …
description: The USA legal soap improbably became the show of the summer after it landed on Netflix. Here’s what to watch after you finish or just get tired of it.
content: For reasons no one can quite decipher, the legal soap “Suits,” which aired on USA from 2011-2019, has become the show of the summer. While it was popular enough when it aired, I’ve read more “Suits” articles in the last few weeks than during the show’s entire run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Tennessee G.O.P. Again Silences Democratic Lawmaker Justin Jones
description: Republicans voted to cut Mr. Jones, who was expelled from the House in April, out of all debate after he was deemed to have breached new stricter rules of decorum.
content: Tennessee’s House Republicans on Monday again silenced Representative Justin Jones, a Black Democrat who was expelled earlier this year in a gun control protest, after he was deemed to have violated new stringent rules of decorum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Venice Film Festival 2023: What to Watch For
description: New films from David Fincher, Sofia Coppola, Ava DuVernay and Michael Mann will make up for the absence of stars kept away by the Hollywood strikes.
content: A year ago, the Venice Film Festival had enough star power to put even celebrity-worshiping Cannes on notice. Highlights were quickly beamed all over the world, including the notorious “Don’t Worry Darling” kickoff that fueled endless speculation about the film’s director, Olivia Wilde, and her stars Florence Pugh and Harry Styles; the news conference where an unexpectedly sagacious Timothée Chalamet predicted imminent societal collapse; and the tearful Brendan Fraser comeback that began on the Lido and culminated in his best actor Oscar win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Uganda Arrests Man on Antigay Charge Punishable by Death
description: Prosecutors used the death penalty provision of a newly passed law to charge a 20-year-old man. The measure has sown widespread fear among gay Ugandans.
content: Ugandan prosecutors have lodged charges of “aggravated homosexuality” against a 20-year-old man — a crime punishable by death — in one of the country’s first applications of a provision included in one of the world’s harshest antigay laws.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Biden Administration Selects Drugs for Medicare Price Negotiations
description: After his administration announced the first set of medications selected for Medicare price negotiations, President Biden vowed to continue standing up to the pharmaceutical industry over the cost of drugs.
